questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment that uses Direct Routing.

You connect a new Session Border Controller (SBC).

You need to verify that all the voice features work as expected for calls that traverse the SBC.

What should you use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The script submits an SIP test to the test runner, waits for the result, and then presents it in a human-readable format. You can use this script to test the following scenarios:

Outbound and inbound calls
Simultaneous ring
Media escalation
Consultative transfer
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/sip-tester-powershell-script

Selected Answer: C
Script is the way to go, NAT does not fulfil the requirements.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

Your company has a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment and the following departments:

• Sales
• Research

You have the users shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You need to meet the following requirements:

• User2 must be able to receive and make calls on behalf of User1.
• User4 and User5 must not hear a ring tone and must see only a banner in the Teams client when User3 receives a call.

What should you configure to meet each requirement? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content: It should be "Yes, No, No." The caller ID will not be shown automatically. The agent number will be shown by default, unless the agent chooses the resource account caller ID on the dial pad.

comments.content:
I think the 3rd one should be Yes as well:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/create-a-phone-system-call-queue?tabs=agent-selection

Serial routing rings all call agents one by one in the order specified in the Call agents list. If an agent dismisses or doesn't pick up a call, the call will ring the next agent. This cycle repeats until the call is answered, times out, or the caller hangs up.

The call answering option is a Team so the order for agents to ring will be based on their AD order (alphabetically) the order cannot be changed by the Admin. The answer should be "no" for the third one.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.

You are configuring emergency services for Direct Routing.

You need to notify a group of users when an emergency number is dialed.

What should you configure in the Microsoft Teams admin center?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

choices.A: The tenant is missing a vanity domain ofvoice.contoso.com.
choices.C: Microsoft 365 Phone System licenses are not assigned to the users.
choices.D: The certificate does not match the FQDN of the SBC.
choices.B: The firewall blocks inbound traffic on port 443 to the SBC.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D : Certificate issue

Selected Answer: D
This is a cert issue.

Selected Answer: A
If TLS certificate has issues, it would show failed in TLS connectivity status. But in this case it does not receive SIP option which is most likely because of a missing vanity domain
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/troubleshoot/phone-system/direct-routing/sip-options-tls-certificate-issues#overview-of-the-sip-options-process

comments.content: I am sorry, you are incorrect! A vanity domain or not, if there exists a mismatch in the domain name on the cert and the PBX you will have this issue.
Seems that both a missing vanity domain and an issue with the TLS certificate can cause SIP OPTIONS requests to fail without a response...

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.

You are deploying Direct Routing.

All users have a SIP URI in the format of user@contoso.com. The Session Border Controller (SBC) is named sbc.voice.contoso.com.

When troubleshooting errors on the SBC, you receive the warning shown in the following exhibit.

//IMG//


What is a possible cause of the issue?
